--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "chbeer78" <Christian.beer@d...> wrote:
> Up to my question: What is the best way to test units, that create
> files (in my case they are PDF files).
> 
> I see two oppinions for that (my case: PDFs) :
> 
> 1) visual testing (no automation)
> 
> 2) visual testing + file comparison (create a pdf that fits your needs
> and check created files against that by file comparison; critical with
> PDFs because two different PDF may look the same :-/ )
> 
> What is your opinion about that? Or am I seeing something wrong? Or is
> it impossible to JUnit-test file creation?

Christian,

I've worked on two different projects that created PDF files. We had
unit tests for both projects, and found little difficulty doing this.

We did have a couple tests that caused pdf files to be created on the
disk, but these were more like acceptance tests or integration tests.
 (In these projects, we did not strongly distinguish between
unit/integration/system/acceptance tests.)

BUT, each time we added a capability to the PDF generator, we tested
that capability.  Usually, that meant creating the pdf snippet either
as a String, or by writing the snippet to a Writer/OutputStream.
Something like "Does the pie chart generator produce the proper pdf
for this case? For that case?"

hth,
Eric
